item.title: 4.1 Wallet Addresses Analysis
item.description: Wallet addresses are a fundamental part of the way cryptocurrencies work. Every time someone sends or receives a digital asset, they do so using a unique wallet address that acts as a sort of virtual post box. This address allows the transaction to be securely recorded on the blockchain, where it can be verified and confirmed by other users.

item.title: 4.1 [Beginner] GameFi Data Analysis
item.description: GameFi is a term used to describe the intersection of gaming and blockchain technology in the context of web3. In web3, blockchain technology is used to enable new forms of decentralized applications and services that allow users to interact with each other in a trustless manner without the need for a central authority.
item.dc:creator: Footprint Analytics

item.title: 2.5 [Intermediate] EVM Gas Analysis
item.description: Gas, like the need to burn fuel while driving, is critical to the recording of blockchain information and refers to the amount of computational work required to perform a particular operation on the blockchain.
item.dc:creator: Footprint Analytics

item.title: 1.2 [Beginner] Footprint Analytics
item.description: The open data of the blockchain isn‚Äôt worth anything unless people can access and understand it. Those new to crypto tend to look at token prices exclusively, which is easy enough. However, as people gain experience in blockchain, they realize that to truly understand the market, one needs to pool-level data for DeFi, retention data for GameFi, and more‚Äîthink about TVL, wallet info and deposits/withdrawals.
item.dc:creator: Footprint Analytics

item.title: 1.1 [Beginner] Data in Web3
item.description: On-chain data refers to data that is recorded on a blockchain. Because a blockchain is a distributed database, on-chain data is publicly available and can be accessed by anyone.

item.title: 1.6 [Advanced] Comparing Footprint and Dune data models
item.description: Data ownership and transfer has fast become one of the key problems to be solved when it comes to product building. The rise of social media platforms misusing data has led to the need to build solutions to solve data misuse. Given this, blockchains provide a functionality to immutably store, transfer data and create marketplaces allowing users to monetise their data.
